ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained in-depth knowledge on Iran and its numerous representations. I had never taken an anthropology course and this was a great introduction to ethnographic writing and reading.

I gained a variety of insights on the history, culture, and perceptions of Iran through this course. Most importantly, this course gave the opportunity to study the politics and culture of Iran outside of the context of its relationship with the United States.
Close reading. Presentation skills. Anthropological analysis.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: No major weaknesses of this course and many strengths. The reading list was absolutely incredible, I never once was bored with any of the readings assigned. The syllabus is also varied that there is something that will interest everyone.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely! Representing Iran was one of my favorite classes at Yale so far. The reading was engaging, the discussion fruitful, the workload manageable and Professor Erami is an excellent educator.
